we can get the ciphertext [ùêÄ(k)]p‚Äãksubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptùêÄùëòùëùùëò[\mathbf{A}^{(k)}]_{pk} with addition and rotation operations.

Appendix C Matrix Transposition on Packed Ciphertexts

In this section, we introduce how to homomorphically transpose a matrix under the packed ciphertext. Let ùêö=Œπ‚àí1‚Äã(A)‚ààRnùêösuperscriptùúÑ1ùê¥superscriptùëÖùëõ\mathbf{a}=\iota^{-1}(A)\in R^{n} indicate the vector representation of a matrix Aùê¥A, UTsuperscriptùëàùëáU^{T} is defined as the matrix representation of the transpose map A‚Ü¶ATmaps-toùê¥superscriptùê¥ùëáA\mapsto A^{T} on Rh√óh‚âÖRnsuperscriptùëÖ‚Ñé‚ÑésuperscriptùëÖùëõR^{h\times h}\cong R^{n}. Then, for 0‚â§i,j<hformulae-sequence0ùëñùëó‚Ñé0\leq i,j<h, each element in UTsuperscriptùëàùëáU^{T} can be expressed as

Uh‚ãÖi+j,kT={1‚ÄãùóÇùñø‚Äãk=h‚ãÖj+i;0‚ÄãùóàùóçùóÅùñæùóãùóêùóÇùóåùñæ.{U}_{h\cdot i+j,k}^{T}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &1\quad\mathsf{if}\;k=h\cdot j+i;\\ &0\quad\mathsf{otherwise}.\\ \end{aligned}\right.

Hence, the kùëòk-th diagonal vector of UTsuperscriptùëàùëáU^{T} is nonzero if and only if k=(h‚àí1)‚ãÖiùëò‚ãÖ‚Ñé1ùëñk=(h-1)\cdot i for some i‚àà‚Ñ§‚à©(‚àíh,h)ùëñ‚Ñ§‚Ñé‚Ñéi\in\mathbb{Z}\cap(-h,h). As a result, UTsuperscriptùëàùëáU^{T} has a total of (2‚Äãh‚àí1)2‚Ñé1(2h-1) nonzero diagonal vectors as a sparse matrix. Therefore, linear transformation for matrix transpose can be expressed as

UT‚ãÖùêö=‚àë‚àíh<i<h(ùê≠(h‚àí1)‚ãÖi‚äôùêë‚Äã(ùêö,(h‚àí1)‚ãÖi))‚ãÖsuperscriptùëàùëáùêösubscript‚Ñéùëñ‚Ñédirect-productsubscriptùê≠‚ãÖ‚Ñé1ùëñùêëùêö‚ãÖ‚Ñé1ùëñ\begin{split}U^{T}\cdot\mathbf{a}=\sum_{-h<i<h}(\mathbf{t}_{(h-1)\cdot i}\odot\mathbf{R}(\mathbf{a},(h-1)\cdot i))\end{split} (18)

where we use ùê≠(h‚àí1)‚ãÖisubscriptùê≠‚ãÖ‚Ñé1ùëñ\mathbf{t}_{(h-1)\cdot i} to represent the nonzero diagonal vector of UTsuperscriptùëàùëáU^{T}. When i‚â•0ùëñ0i\geq 0, the tùë°t-th component of the vector ùê≠(h‚àí1)‚ãÖisubscriptùê≠‚ãÖ‚Ñé1ùëñ\mathbf{t}_{(h-1)\cdot i} is computed by

ùê≠(h‚àí1)‚ãÖi[t]={1‚ÄãùóÇùñø‚Äãt‚àíi=(h+1)‚ãÖj,0‚â§j<h‚àíi;0‚ÄãùóàùóçùóÅùñæùóãùóêùóÇùóåùñæ.\mathbf{t}_{(h-1)\cdot i}[t]=\left\{\begin{aligned} &1\quad\mathsf{if}\;t-i=(h+1)\cdot j,0\leq j<h-i;\\ &0\quad\mathsf{otherwise}.\\ \end{aligned}\right.

If i‚â§0ùëñ0i\leq 0, we have

ùê≠(h‚àí1)‚ãÖi[t]={1‚ÄãùóÇùñø‚Äãt+i=(h+1)‚ãÖj,0‚â§j<h+i;0‚ÄãùóàùóçùóÅùñæùóãùóêùóÇùóåùñæ.\mathbf{t}_{(h-1)\cdot i}[t]=\left\{\begin{aligned} &1\quad\mathsf{if}\;t+i=(h+1)\cdot j,0\leq j<h+i;\\ &0\quad\mathsf{otherwise}.\\ \end{aligned}\right.

In general, the computation cost required for matrix transposition is about 2‚Äãh2‚Ñé2h rotations, which can be further reduced to 3‚Äãh3‚Ñé3\sqrt{h} by the previously described baby-step/giant-step method.

Appendix D Rectangular Matrix Multiplication on Packed Ciphertexts

We extend the homomorphic multiplication between square matrices to general rectangular matrices, such as Rt√óh√óRh√óh‚ÜíRt√óh‚ÜísuperscriptùëÖùë°‚ÑésuperscriptùëÖ‚Ñé‚ÑésuperscriptùëÖùë°‚ÑéR^{t\times h}\times R^{h\times h}\rightarrow R^{t\times h} or Rh√óh√óRh√ót‚ÜíRh√ót‚ÜísuperscriptùëÖ‚Ñé‚ÑésuperscriptùëÖ‚Ñéùë°superscriptùëÖ‚Ñéùë°R^{h\times h}\times R^{h\times t}\rightarrow R^{h\times t}. Without loss of generality, we consider t<hùë°‚Ñét<h. For a (h1√óh)subscript‚Ñé1‚Ñé(h_{1}\times h)-dimensional matrix A1subscriptùê¥1A_{1} and a (h2√óh)subscript‚Ñé2‚Ñé(h_{2}\times h)-dimensional matrix A2subscriptùê¥2A_{2}, we use (A1;A2)subscriptùê¥1subscriptùê¥2(A_{1};A_{2}) to represent the (h1+h2)√óhsubscript‚Ñé1subscript‚Ñé2‚Ñé(h_{1}+h_{2})\times h matrix which is obtained by concatenating A1subscriptùê¥1A_{1} and A2subscriptùê¥2A_{2} in a vertical direction. Similarly, (A1|A2)conditionalsubscriptùê¥1subscriptùê¥2(A_{1}|A_{2}) indicates the matrix concatenated in a horizontal direction if matrices A1subscriptùê¥1A_{1} and A2subscriptùê¥2A_{2} have the same number of rows.

A naive solution to perform multiplication between rectangular matrices is to convert any matrix into a square matrix through zero padding, and then use Algorithm¬†3 to implement the multiplication between square matrices homomorphically. This leads to a rotation with a complexity of O‚Äã(h)ùëÇ‚ÑéO(h). We provide an improved method through insight into the property of matrix permutation.
Refined Rectangular Matrix Multiplication. Given a t√óhùë°‚Ñét\times h matrix Aùê¥A and an h√óh‚Ñé‚Ñéh\times h matrix BùêµB with tùë°t divide h‚Ñéh, we introduce a new symbol Ct1:t2subscriptùê∂:subscriptùë°1subscriptùë°2C_{t_{1}:t_{2}}, which is denoted the (t2‚àít1)√óhsubscriptùë°2subscriptùë°1‚Ñé(t_{2}-t_{1})\times h submatrix of Cùê∂C formed by extracting from t1subscriptùë°1t_{1}-th row to the (t2‚àí1)subscriptùë°21(t_{2}-1)-th row of Cùê∂C. As a result, the product of A‚ÄãBùê¥ùêµAB can be expressed as below.

Our key observation is the following lemma, which provides us with ideas for designing fast rectangular matrix multiplication.

(œïi‚àòŒº‚Äã(A~))j‚ãÖt:(j+1)‚ãÖt=(œïi‚àòŒº‚Äã(A~)j‚ãÖt:(j+1)‚ãÖt)=œïi‚àòŒº‚àòœïj‚ãÖt‚Äã(A)=œïj‚ãÖt+i‚àòŒº‚Äã(A)subscriptsuperscriptitalic-œïùëñùúá~ùê¥:‚ãÖùëóùë°‚ãÖùëó1ùë°superscriptitalic-œïùëñùúásubscript~ùê¥:‚ãÖùëóùë°‚ãÖùëó1ùë°superscriptitalic-œïùëñùúásuperscriptitalic-œï‚ãÖùëóùë°ùê¥superscriptitalic-œï‚ãÖùëóùë°ùëñùúáùê¥\begin{split}(\phi^{i}\circ\mu(\tilde{A}))_{j\cdot t:(j+1)\cdot t}&=(\phi^{i}\circ\mu(\tilde{A})_{j\cdot t:(j+1)\cdot t})\\ &=\phi^{i}\circ\mu\circ\phi^{j\cdot t}(A)\\ &=\phi^{j\cdot t+i}\circ\mu(A)\end{split} (20)

Homomorphic Rectangular Matrix Multiplication. Table¬†V presents the total complexity of Algorithm¬†6. We observe that compared with Algorithm¬†3, it reduces the complexity of the rotation operations of steps 2 and 3 to O‚Äã(t)ùëÇùë°O(t), although additional operation is required for step 4. Moreover, the final result [ùêÄùêÅ]p‚Äãksubscriptdelimited-[]ùêÄùêÅùëùùëò[\mathbf{AB}]_{pk} is a ciphertext of a h√óh‚Ñé‚Ñéh\times h-dimensional matrix containing (h/t)‚Ñéùë°(h/t) copies of the expected matrix product A‚ÄãBùê¥ùêµAB in a vertical direction. Hence, the resulting ciphertext remains the format as a rectangular matrix, and it can be further performed matrix calculations without additional overhead.

Appendix E Parallel Matrix Computation

The above matrix operations are all performed in the message space RnsuperscriptùëÖùëõR^{n}, where we assume that n=h2ùëõsuperscript‚Ñé2n=h^{2}. Actually, most HE schemes have a lot of plaintext slots (up to thousands) compared to the dimension of the matrix in deep learning, that is, usually n‚â´h2much-greater-thanùëõsuperscript‚Ñé2n\gg h^{2}. Hence, most plaintext slots will be wasted if a ciphertext is only used to store a matrix. We provide a method of encrypting multiple matrices into a ciphertext, so as to realize parallel matrix calculation in a SIMD manner. Specifically, we assume that nùëõn is divisible by h‚Ñéh and let Œ≤=n/h2ùõΩùëõsuperscript‚Ñé2\beta=n/h^{2}. Then the encoding map described in above for singe matrix will be modified as ŒπŒ≤:Rn‚Üí(Rh√óh)Œ≤:subscriptùúÑùõΩ‚ÜísuperscriptùëÖùëõsuperscriptsuperscriptùëÖ‚Ñé‚ÑéùõΩ\iota_{\beta}:R^{n}\rightarrow(R^{h\times h})^{\beta}. For an input vector ùêö=(at)0‚â§t<nùêösubscriptsubscriptùëéùë°0ùë°ùëõ\mathbf{a}=(a_{t})_{0\leq t<n}, ŒπŒ≤subscriptùúÑùõΩ\iota_{\beta} is defined as below.

ŒπŒ≤:ùêö‚Ü¶(Ak=(aŒ≤‚Äã(h‚ãÖi+j)+k))0‚â§k<Œ≤.:subscriptùúÑùõΩmaps-toùêösubscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëòsubscriptùëéùõΩ‚ãÖ‚Ñéùëñùëóùëò0ùëòùõΩ\begin{split}\iota_{\beta}:\mathbf{a}\mapsto\left(A_{k}=(a_{\beta(h\cdot i+j)+k})\right)_{0\leq k<\beta}.\end{split} (22)

The components of ùêöùêö\mathbf{a} with indexes congruent to kùëòk modulo Œ≤ùõΩ\beta are corresponding to the kùëòk-th matrix Aksubscriptùê¥ùëòA_{k}. We observe that for an integer 0‚â§t<h20ùë°superscript‚Ñé20\leq t<h^{2}, the rotation operation ùêë‚Äã(ùêö,Œ≤‚Äãt)ùêëùêöùõΩùë°\mathbf{R}(\mathbf{a},\beta t) represents the matrix-wise rotation by Œ≤ùõΩ\beta positions. This can be naturally extended to other operations including scalar linear conversion and matrix multiplication. For example, when a single ciphertext is embedded in Œ≤ùõΩ\beta (h√óh‚Ñé‚Ñéh\times h)-dimensional matrices, we can immediately perform matrix multiplication between Œ≤ùõΩ\beta pairs matrices by using the previously described algorithm on two ciphertexts. This total computation complexity is consistent with Algorithm¬†3, but results in a less amortized computation complexity of O‚Äã(h/Œ≤)ùëÇ‚ÑéùõΩO(h/\beta) for each matrix.

Appendix F Proof of Lemma ¬†4.1

Proof (Sketch).

We use induction to prove it. First, it is true for n=1. Assume that pd=2‚Äãd+14d‚Äã(2‚Äãdd)subscriptùëùùëë2ùëë1superscript4ùëëmatrix2ùëëùëëp_{d}=\frac{2d+1}{4^{d}}\begin{pmatrix}2d\\ d\end{pmatrix} for some d‚â§1ùëë1d\leq 1, Hence, we have

pd+1=pd+14d+1‚Äã(2‚Äãd+2d+1)=14d+1‚Äã(2‚Äã(2‚Äãd+2)!(d+1)!‚Äãd!+(2‚Äãd+2)!(d+1)!‚Äã(d+1)!)=2‚Äãd+34d+1‚Äã(2‚Äãd+2d+1)subscriptùëùùëë1subscriptùëùùëë1superscript4ùëë1matrix2ùëë2ùëë11superscript4ùëë122ùëë2ùëë1ùëë2ùëë2ùëë1ùëë12ùëë3superscript4ùëë1matrix2ùëë2ùëë1\begin{split}p_{d+1}&=p_{d}+\frac{1}{4^{d+1}}\begin{pmatrix}2d+2\\ d+1\end{pmatrix}\\ &=\frac{1}{4^{d+1}}\left(\frac{2(2d+2)!}{(d+1)!d!}+\frac{(2d+2)!}{(d+1)!(d+1)!}\right)\\ &=\frac{2d+3}{4^{d+1}}\begin{pmatrix}2d+2\\ d+1\end{pmatrix}\end{split}

Hence, the lemma is proved by induction. ‚àé

Appendix I Experimental comparisons with work [34]

TABLE¬†VI shows the running times of work [34] and our method for approximation of the sign function, where Œ¥ùõø\delta is used to represent the error bound, i.e., 2‚àíœÉsuperscript2ùúé2^{-\sigma} means that the value error of the original function and the approximated function is small than 2‚àíœÉsuperscript2ùúé2^{-\sigma}, ùí©=214ùí©superscript214\mathcal{N}=2^{14} and Q‚Ñí=22250subscriptùëÑ‚Ñísuperscript22250Q_{\mathcal{L}}=2^{2250}. Appendix J Details Implementation of Hercules

Figure¬†5 presents the details of implementing Hercules, which essentially executes Algorithm¬†1 under the ciphertext. Note that we assume that all matrices involved in training have the same dimensions for simplicity. In actual implementation, the user can adaptively select the dimension so as to use Algorithm ¬†3 or 6 to obtain the ciphertext result. ùêëùêí‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùêëùêí‚ãÖ\mathbf{RS}(\cdot) is used to resulting ciphertext after each multiplication. This means that for the ciphertext with an initial layer number of ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathcal{L}, the maximum depth of ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathcal{L} ciphertext multiplication can be evaluated. In practical applications, assuming Q‚Ñí/Œî=rsubscriptùëÑ‚ÑíŒîùëüQ_{\mathcal{L}}/\Delta=r, the ciphertext can be rescaled after rùëür multiplications instead of after each multiplication. On the other hand, Figure¬†5 only requires each user to perform the distributed bootstrapping function (i.e., ùêÉùêÅùê®ùê®ùê≠ùê¨ùê≠ùê´ùêöùê©ùêÉùêÅùê®ùê®ùê≠ùê¨ùê≠ùê´ùêöùê©\mathbf{DBootstrap}) when calculating the activation function, because this process usually requires more circuit depth. Similarly, in practice, users can adaptively execute ùêÉùêÅùê®ùê®ùê≠ùê¨ùê≠ùê´ùêöùê©ùêÉùêÅùê®ùê®ùê≠ùê¨ùê≠ùê´ùêöùê©\mathbf{DBootstrap} as long as the depth of the circuit is about to be exhausted.

Appendix K Datasets Used in Experiments

Consistent with POSEIDON [12], we choose the following public datasets in our experiments.

  • a.

    The Breast Cancer Wisconsin dataset (BCW) [45], which has a total of |D|=699ùê∑699|D|=699 samples, and the dimension of each sample is h=9‚Ñé9h=9, with œâùïÉ=2subscriptùúîùïÉ2\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=2, where œâùïÉsubscriptùúîùïÉ\omega_{\mathbb{L}} represents the number of labels (also the number of neurons in the last layer of the neural network (NN)).

  • b.

    MNIST dataset [46] with |D|=70,000ùê∑70000|D|=70,000, h=28√ó28‚Ñé2828h=28\times 28, and œâùïÉ=10subscriptùúîùïÉ10\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=10.

  • c.

    The Epileptic seizure recognition (ESR) dataset [47] with |D|=11,500ùê∑11500|D|=11,500, h=179‚Ñé179h=179, and œâùïÉ=2subscriptùúîùïÉ2\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=2.

  • d.

    The default of credit card clients (CREDIT) [48] with |D|=30,000ùê∑30000|D|=30,000, h=23‚Ñé23h=23, and œâùïÉ=2subscriptùúîùïÉ2\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=2.

  • e.

    The street view house numbers (SVHN) dataset [49] with colored images (3 channels), with |D|=600,000ùê∑600000|D|=600,000, h=3√ó32√ó32‚Ñé33232h=3\times 32\times 32, and œâùïÉ=10subscriptùúîùïÉ10\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=10.

  • f.

    CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 with |D|=60,500ùê∑60500|D|=60,500, h=3√ó32√ó32‚Ñé33232h=3\times 32\times 32, œâùïÉ=10subscriptùúîùïÉ10\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=10, and œâùïÉ=100subscriptùúîùïÉ100\omega_{\mathbb{L}}=100, respectively.

We convert SVHN to gray-scale to reduce the number of channels. In addition, we make the dimension of each weight matrix to the nearest power of 2 by padding zeros. As a result, we actually train the NN on the CREDIT, ESR, and MNIST datasets with the feature dimensions of 32, 256, 1024, respectively. Since SVHN is grayed out, the dimension of its features already meets the power of 2. On the other hand, we generate synthetic data to evaluate the scalability of the system, where we record the system performance under different features or the number of samples. For simplicity, we uniformly and randomly distribute all the above datasets to users. Note that the distribution of data among different users may affect the accuracy of the model, but this is orthogonal to the focus of this paper. Since Hercules is designed for general federated learning scenario, all existing processing strategies for data distribution can be seamlessly integrated into Hercules.

Appendix L Neural Network Structure

We use the following NN structures to train specific datasets.

  • a.

    We train a 2-layer fully connected NN with BCW, ESR and CREDIT data sets, where each layer contains 646464 neurons. Similarly, the same structure was used to test the cost of Hercules on the synthetic dataset.

  • b.

    We train a three-layer fully connected NN with 64 neurons in each layer for the MNIST and SVHN datasets.

  • c.

    We train two models for CIFAR-10 dataset. Specifically, (i) a CNN structure contains 222 convolutional layers (CV), an average pooling layer, a max pooling layer with kernel size of 2√ó2222\times 2, and two fully connected layer (FC) which contains 128128128 and 101010 neurons, respectively. We called this structure as CIFAR-10-N1. (ii) a CNN structure contains 444 CV with kernel size of 3√ó4343\times 4, an average pooling layer and a max pooling layer with kernel size of 2√ó2222\times 2, and 2 FC which contain 128128128 and 101010 neurons, respectively. We called this structure as CIFAR-10-N2.

  • d.

    For CIFAR-100, we train a CNN structure consisting of 666 CV with kernel size of 3√ó4343\times 4, an average pooling layer and a max pooling layer with kernel size of 2√ó2222\times 2, and 2 FC which contain 128128128 neurons for each layer.

We changed the number of filters from 3 to 16 for all CV layers. The number of global iterations used to train the above models is 100; 500; 600; 1000; 18,000; 16,800; 25,000 and 54,000 for BCW, CREDIT, ESR, MNIST, SVHN, CIFAR-10-N2, CIFAR-10-N1, and CIFAR-100, respectively. The local batch size of each user is set to 10, thus the global batch size is 100 for 10 users, and 500 for 50 users.

Appendix M Learning Extensions

M.1 Asynchronous distributed learning with uneven data distribution

In Hercules, we rely on all users online to complete the global update of the gradient under the ciphertext. However, Hercules also supports asynchronous neural network learning, which can be realized by the server only receiving data from users within a certain threshold time. In this case, the training of the neural network mainly benefits from the local data of users with good network status. Noted that the smooth execution of the distributed bootstrapping operation ùêÉùêÅùê®ùê®ùê≠ùê¨ùê≠ùê´ùêöùê©ùêÉùêÅùê®ùê®ùê≠ùê¨ùê≠ùê´ùêöùê©\mathbf{DBootstrap} requires the participation of all users. This operation instead of being done in a centralized manner usually requires more computation and communication overhead.

In Hercules, we evenly distribute the data to each user for the simplicity of the experiment. In fact, the uneven distribution of users‚Äô data and asynchronous gradient descent will inevitably affect the accuracy of the model. How to deal with these problems has been extensively studied [59, 60], which are orthogonal to this work. Note that our privacy protection method is independent of the distribution of user data and the way of gradient update. Hence, all existing works can be seamlessly integrated into Hercules.

M.2 Training on Other Neural Networks

In this work, we focus on deploying Hercules on MLPs and CNNs, and demonstrate the performance of our packing scheme and function approximation method under these NNs. For other structures, such as long short-term memory (LSTM)[61], recurrent neural network (RNN)[62] and residual neural network (ResNet) [63], Hercules needs to modify the local gradient update process according to their forward and backward pass operations. For example, ResNet has skip connections to skip certain layers, so after skipping a layer, the shape of the encrypted ciphertext should be aligned according to the weight matrix to be multiplied. This can be ensured by using the rotation function of CKKS (rearrange the slots of the ciphertext). We believe that these modifications are not significant. Although POSEIDON is tailored for MLPs and CNNs, in essence, Hercules can be used to quickly calculate any mathematical operation under ciphertext, which constitutes the main body of other neural network structures.

Appendix N Microbenchmarks of Hercules and POSEIDON

We present the microbenchmark cost of Hercules and POSEIDON in performing different functions. As shown in Table¬†VIII, the bold font represents the overhead of Hercules. For experimental configurations, We consider the number of users N=10ùëÅ10N=10, the dimension of each sample is h=32‚Ñé32h=32, the number of neurons in each layer is 64 or with kernel size 3√ó3333\times 3, and the dimension of cyclotomic polynomial ring used in CKKS is set ùí©=213ùí©superscript213\mathcal{N}=2^{13}. All the costs represent the processing of 1 sample per party.

We record the computation and communication costs (in an amortized way) of calculating FC, CV, FC backpropagation, CV backpropagation, and different activation functions in Hercules and POSEIDON. For the activation functions sigmoid and sofmax, Hercules and POSEIDON exhibit the same overhead because they both use the same function approximation method. For ReLU, since Hercules uses a 20 bit-precision composite polynomial to fit the original function, while POSEIDON simply uses a polynomial with a degree of 3 to approximate the original ReLU (using the least squares method), it makes the cost of Hercules larger than POSEIDON but derives a higher approximation accuracy. Note that given the same error bound, the time required to calculate the polynomial generated by the least square method under ciphertext is much longer than ours. For max pooling, POSEIDON replaces it with Chebyshev function interpolation, thereby obtaining a polynomial of degree 31 with a precision of 7 bits. Experimental results show that our 7-bit precision composite polynomial is much less expensive than POSEIDON. This is mainly due to the characteristics of composite polynomials. As discussed before, a composite function with degree of d‚Äãe‚Äãg‚Äã(G)ùëëùëíùëîùê∫deg(G) can be calculated with a complexity of O‚Äã(log‚Å°(d‚Äãe‚Äãg‚Äã(G)))ùëÇùëëùëíùëîùê∫O(\log(deg(G))), while the computation complexity of calculating any function Gùê∫G is at least Œò‚Äã(d‚Äãe‚Äãg‚Äã(G))Œòùëëùëíùëîùê∫\Theta(\sqrt{deg(G)}).

The operations in FC, CV and their backpropagation are mainly composed of matrix multiplication. As shown in Table¬†VIII, Hercules is far superior to POSEIDON in terms of calculating homomorphic matrix multiplication. Specifically, POSEIDON adopts AP to achieve fast SIMD calculations. For the multiplication of two h√óh‚Ñé‚Ñéh\times h-dimensional matrices, the complexity of the homomorphic rotation operation required by AP is maxi‚àà[ùïÉ]‚Å°(œâi√ólog‚Å°(h√óœâi))subscriptùëñdelimited-[]ùïÉsubscriptùúîùëñ‚Ñésubscriptùúîùëñ\max_{i\in[\mathbb{L}]}(\omega_{i}\times\log(h\times\omega_{i})). For Hercules, as shown in Table¬†I, the complexity required for the matrix multiplication is only 3‚Äãh+5‚Äãh3‚Ñé5‚Ñé3h+5\sqrt{h}. Moreover, AP requires multiple copies and zero padding operations for each row or column of the input matrix, (depending on the number of neurons in each hidden layer, and the absolute value of the difference between the row or column dimension of the matrix and the corresponding hidden layer neuron. On the contrary, our method does not require additional element copying except for a small amount of zero padding in the initial stage to facilitate calculations. Therefore, Hercules obviously exhibits lower communication overhead.

Appendix O Storage Overhead

As shown in TABLE¬†IX, we also count the storage overhead required for training each scheme on different datasets, where the storage overhead is mainly dominated by the size of the ciphertext that each user needs to save locally. We observe that the storage overhead required by Hercules on each dataset is much lower than that of POSEIDON. Since POSEIDON designs a alternating packing (AP) method to pack ciphertext in the encryption process, this leads to multiple copies and zero padding operations for each ciphertext, depending on the number of neurons in each hidden layer. On the contrary, our method does not require additional element copying except for a small amount of zero padding in the initial stage to facilitate calculations.

Appendix P Comparison with Other Prior Works

Beyond the HE-based schemes, a wealth of MPC solutions based on interaction between multiple servers have been proposed to design privacy-preserving neural network training and prediction frameworks. These solutions may be not practical in the real-world setting without multiple servers. Nevertheless, we still make a rough comparison between these works and Hercules to demonstrate the merits and demerits of each scheme. As shown in Table¬†VII in the Appendix, MPC protocol with multiple servers relies on splitting the training task into two or more servers, where the servers are usually assumed to be non-colluding. Then, the state-of-the-art secret sharing methods, including arithmetic sharing [19], boolean sharing [8], and Yao‚Äôs garbled circuit [21] are carefully integrated to efficiently implement various mathematical operations under the ciphertext. It is computationally cost-effective, avoiding the high communication overhead among large-scale users. For example, given the MNIST dataset, we roughly compare the computational cost of Hercules, ABY3 [8], and XONN [58] in training the same network architecture. Here we use a three-layer architecture with 128 neurons in each layer. The number of users in Hercules is set to 3 and the global training epoch is set to 15. Experimental results show that Hercules requires a total of 24.3 hours to train such a model, while ABY3 and XONN need 1.02 and 0.58 hours, respectively. We remind that Hercules is operated in a different scenario (FL) and threat model from those MPC-based schemes. It supports more participants with collusion, and the cost only grows linearly with the number of users. In contrast, those MPC-based solutions require to outsource training tasks among limited computing servers, which may be impractical in some scenarios.
